fields.description:
*Assessment*

On a Eucalyptus 4.0.1 Cloud with Eucalyptus enabled, if a user tries to resolve a bucket on the OSG, the following is returned:
{code}
# nslookup s3cmd-testing.objectstorage.future.euca-hasp.cs.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com
Server:		10.1.1.254
Address:	10.1.1.254#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:	s3cmd-testing.objectstorage.future.euca-hasp.cs.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com
Address: 10.104.1.186
{code}

This does not match AWS behavior:
{code}
$ nslookup coverity-docs.s3.amazonaws.com
Server:		10.1.1.254
Address:	10.1.1.254#53

Non-authoritative answer:
coverity-docs.s3.amazonaws.com	canonical name = s3-1-w.amazonaws.com.
Name:	s3-1-w.amazonaws.com
Address: 54.231.2.185
{code}

*Details*

More detailed information using dig:

_Eucalyptus_
{code}
$ dig s3cmd-testing.objectstorage.future.euca-hasp.cs.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com

; <<>> DiG 9.10.0-P2 <<>> s3cmd-testing.objectstorage.future.euca-hasp.cs.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 41173
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 2

;; OPT PSEUDOSECTION:
; EDNS: version: 0, flags:; udp: 4096
;; QUESTION SECTION:
;s3cmd-testing.objectstorage.future.euca-hasp.cs.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com. IN A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
s3cmd-testing.objectstorage.future.euca-hasp.cs.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com. 20 IN A 10.104.1.186

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
future.euca-hasp.cs.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com.	602633 IN NS odc-f-13.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com.

;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:
odc-f-13.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com. 10800 IN A	10.104.10.55

;; Query time: 235 msec
;; SERVER: 10.1.1.254#53(10.1.1.254)
;; WHEN: Wed Sep 17 15:07:20 EDT 2014
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 158
{code}

_AWS_
{code}
$ dig coverity-docs.s3.amazonaws.com

; <<>> DiG 9.10.0-P2 <<>> coverity-docs.s3.amazonaws.com
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 42853
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 2, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 1

;; OPT PSEUDOSECTION:
; EDNS: version: 0, flags:; udp: 512
;; QUESTION SECTION:
;coverity-docs.s3.amazonaws.com.	IN	A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
coverity-docs.s3.amazonaws.com.	2399 IN	CNAME	s3-1-w.amazonaws.com.
s3-1-w.amazonaws.com.	56	IN	A	54.231.8.73

;; Query time: 68 msec
;; SERVER: 8.8.8.8#53(8.8.8.8)
;; WHEN: Wed Sep 17 15:06:39 EDT 2014
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 96
{code}

*Steps*

# Set up a Eucalyptus 4.0.1 Cloud with Eucalyptus DNS enabled (setting up delegation based upon our documentation)
# Register UFS and set up Walrus as a backend
# Use a tool like s3curl or s3cmd to create a bucket on the OSG
# Use a tool like dig, or nslookup to lookup the DNS name of the bucket
fields.summary: DNS Resolution of Buckets Are Not CNAMES of OSG
fields.environment:
* non-HA, single cluster, Eucalyptus DNS enabled
** 1 x CLC, UFS, Load Balancer
** 1 x UFS
** 1 x UFS, Walrus
** 1 x CC (Managed-NOVLAN), SC (DAS)
** 1 x NC

comments.body:
So the correct behavior would be to use the CNAME of the object storage service?

mybucket.objectstorage.mycloud.com IN CNAME objectstorage.mycloud.com

Then that can be resolved to the specific IPs for object storage hosts. This makes sense for AWS because they are global and dns must direct to the proper region. We'll get to this requirement when we do multi-region S3 support, but it isn't clear to me that this is actually a bug or negatively affects anything at this time? [~hspencer], does this cause issues in clients or with any tools?

I removed the OSG label on this ticket since this is a DNS response problem, not an OSG issue. DNS is completely decoupled from the OSG in that it just responds with OSG RR records if the requested name is a subdomain of the objectstorage subdomain in the cloud. We don't actually check via the OSG that the bucket exists. That means there is a slightly different issue in that you cannot test for bucket existence simply by using DNS requests as they will always return an A record (or RR records). But, that is a different issue and is already not a good practice in S3 because it isn't accurate.
